title: The Psychology of Listicles

multiple-choice.question: Why are listicles so popular?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a new format that has been developed for the internet.

options.label: B
options.text: They are readable and easy to digest, allowing users to quickly process information.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a way to catalog and organize information, a concept that is new to the internet age.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a format that is used only in journalism.

multiple-choice.question: What is cognitive fluency?

options.label: A
options.text: A measure of how easy it is to think about something.

options.label: B
options.text: A measure of how difficult it is to think about something.

options.label: C
options.text: A measure of how much information a person can process at one time.

options.label: D
options.text: A measure of how much time a person spends thinking about something.

multiple-choice.question: What is the capacity of working memory?

options.label: A
options.text: It can hold about 10-20 pieces of information for a short duration.

options.label: B
options.text: It can hold about 4 pieces of information for a short duration.

options.label: C
options.text: It can hold about 100 pieces of information for a long duration.

options.label: D
options.text: It can hold an unlimited amount of information.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main criticism of listicles in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too long and take too much time to read.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too short and do not provide enough information.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not effective in engaging users and leaving a lasting impression.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not a format that should be used in journalism.

multiple-choice.question: Why do listicles activate the brain's reward system?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide a sense of accomplishment when completed.

options.label: B
options.text: They provide a sense of satisfaction when finished.

options.label: C
options.text: They provide a sense of curiosity when started.

options.label: D
options.text: They provide a sense of boredom when finished.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of listicles as a format for education?

options.label: A
options.text: They do not provide enough information on a topic.

options.label: B
options.text: They do not engage users in a meaningful way.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not leave a lasting impression on users.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not a format that should be used for education.

multiple-choice.question: Why should listicles be used in conjunction with other formats?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a more comprehensive understanding of a topic.

options.label: B
options.text: To engage users in a more meaningful way.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a sense of accomplishment when completed.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a sense of boredom when finished.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of cataloging and organizing information?

options.label: A
options.text: A way to provide a list of information on a topic.

options.label: B
options.text: A way to engage users in a meaningful way.

options.label: C
options.text: A way to provide a sense of accomplishment when completed.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to provide a sense of satisfaction when finished.

multiple-choice.question: Why is cognitive fluency important in the context of listicles?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a sense of satisfaction when finished.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a sense of curiosity when started.

options.label: C
options.text: It influences judgments of truth and leads to more positive responses.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not play a role in the context of listicles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a listicle and a piece of education?

options.label: A
options.text: A listicle is a format that should be used in education, while a piece of education is a format that should not be used in education.

options.label: B
options.text: A listicle is a format that engages users in a meaningful way, while a piece of education is a format that does not engage users.

options.label: C
options.text: A listicle is a format that leaves a lasting impression on users, while a piece of education is a format that does not leave a lasting impression.

options.label: D
options.text: A listicle is a format that provides a sense of satisfaction when finished, while a piece of education is a format that does not provide a sense of satisfaction.

title: What are mini brains? - Madeline Lancaster

multiple-choice.question: What is a brain organoid?

options.label: A
options.text: A collection of lab-grown neurons and other brain tissue that scientists can use to learn about full-grown human brains.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of animal model used to study the human brain.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of imaging technique used to study the human brain.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of stem cell used to grow brain tissue.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge that neuroscientists face when studying the human brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding the perfect combination of sugars, proteins, vitamins, and minerals to induce the stem cell to develop a neural identity.

options.label: B
options.text: Shielding by our thick skulls and swaddled in layers of protective tissue.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process of growing a brain organoid?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves finding the perfect combination of sugars, proteins, vitamins, and minerals to induce the stem cell to develop a neural identity.

options.label: B
options.text: It involves using a special gel to simulate embryonic tissue, a warm incubator, and a bit of motion to mimic blood flow.

options.label: C
options.text: It involves using animal models to study the human brain.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves using imaging techniques to study the human brain.

multiple-choice.question: Can brain organoids think for themselves or develop consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, they can think for themselves and develop consciousness.

options.label: B
options.text: No, they cannot think for themselves or develop consciousness.

options.label: C
options.text: Maybe, it depends on the type of brain organoid.

options.label: D
options.text: It's not clear, more research is needed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too small to study.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not organized the same way as a full-sized brain.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not have blood vessels to feed them.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not interact with the outside world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: They can think for themselves and develop consciousness.

options.label: B
options.text: They can be used to study the development of neurons and the formation of neural networks.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be used to study the effect of diseases on the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a cost-effective way to study the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between brain organoids and the outside world?

options.label: A
options.text: Brain organoids can interact with the outside world.

options.label: B
options.text: Brain organoids cannot interact with the outside world.

options.label: C
options.text: It's not clear, more research is needed.

options.label: D
options.text: Brain organoids can only interact with other brain organoids.

multiple-choice.question: What is the size of a brain organoid?

options.label: A
options.text: It can grow up to 100 centimeters in size.

options.label: B
options.text: It can grow up to 10 centimeters in size.

options.label: C
options.text: It is limited to one centimeter at most.

options.label: D
options.text: It can grow up to 50 centimeters in size.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of using brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effect of diseases on the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: To study the development of neurons and the formation of neural networks.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the human brain and discover what makes it unique.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new treatments for brain disorders.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential of brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: They can replace animal models and imaging techniques.

options.label: B
options.text: They can help scientists discover what makes the human brain unique.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be used to develop new treatments for brain disorders.

options.label: D
options.text: They can think for themselves and develop consciousness.

options.text: Replacing the full ranking system with a limited number of priority "buckets."

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the number of tasks that could be run simultaneously.

options.label: D
options.text: Decreasing the priority of certain tasks.

multiple-choice.question: What is the tradeoff between productivity and responsiveness in computer scheduling?

options.label: C
options.text: There is no tradeoff between productivity and responsiveness.

options.label: D
options.text: Productivity and responsiveness are directly proportional.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of interrupt coalescing in computer science?

options.label: A
options.text: Grouping together multiple tasks to be run simultaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: Deferring interruptions to reduce the number of context switches.

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the priority of certain tasks.

options.label: D
options.text: Decreasing the number of tasks that can be run simultaneously.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of implementing interrupt coalescing in laptop battery life in 2013?
What is the potential benefit of adopting a similar approach to interrupt coalescing in humans?

options.label: C
options.text: Reclaiming attention and giving back a sense of rest.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary insight from computer scheduling that relates to human productivity and time management?

options.label: B
options.text: The tradeoff between productivity and responsiveness.

options.label: C
options.text: The need for a linear-time algorithm.

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of minimizing context switches.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of using a quadratic-time algorithm to prioritize tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: Exponential growth in time spent on tasks.

options.label: B
options.text: Linear growth in time spent on tasks.

multiple-choice.question: What is the solution to the problem of minimizing context switches in computer scheduling?

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the number of tasks that can be run simultaneously.

options.label: C
options.text: Deferring interruptions to reduce the number of context switches.

options.label: D
options.text: Decreasing the priority of certain tasks.

title: Why do animals form swarms? - Maria R. D'Orsogna

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of swarming behavior in locusts and other organisms?

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of a single dominant individual

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of swarming behavior in insects and other organisms?
What is an example of a catastrophic consequence of swarming behavior in army ants?

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Only in the realm of social organization

options.label: C
options.text: In various aspects of life, including technology and social organization

options.label: B
options.text: Finding the shortest path to a food source

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of swarming intelligence?
What can swarming behavior in human populations manifest as?
What can swarming behavior in humans be dependent on?
What can swarming behavior in humans be complicated by?

title: Why is Herodotus called “The Father of History”? - Mark Robinson

multiple-choice.question: Who was Herodotus and what was his significance in the field of history?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a Roman historian who wrote about the Persian Wars.

options.label: B
options.text: He was an Ancient Greek writer from the 5th century BCE who revolutionized the way the past was recorded.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a Persian king who fought against the Greeks.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a Greek philosopher who wrote about the nature of reality.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main approach that Herodotus took in writing The Histories?

options.label: A
options.text: He documented events as a list without explaining their causes.

options.label: B
options.text: He looked at events from both sides to understand the reasons for them.

options.label: C
options.text: He focused on the internal debates of the Persian court.

options.label: D
options.text: He recorded tales of Egyptian flying snakes and practical advice on how to catch a crocodile.

multiple-choice.question: Where was Herodotus born and what was his hometown's significance?

options.label: A
options.text: He was born in Athens and his hometown was a city-state in ancient Greece.

options.label: B
options.text: He was born in Halicarnassus, a city part of the Persian Empire.

options.label: C
options.text: He was born in Sparta and his hometown was a city-state in ancient Greece.

options.label: D
options.text: He was born in Persia and his hometown was a city-state in ancient Greece.

multiple-choice.question: What was the original format of The Histories when it was first written?

options.label: A
options.text: It was written in 28 sections, each of which took about four hours to read aloud.

options.label: B
options.text: It was written in a single book with no sections.

options.label: C
options.text: It was written in 10 sections, each of which took about two hours to read aloud.

options.label: D
options.text: It was written in 5 sections, each of which took about one hour to read aloud.

multiple-choice.question: Who gave Herodotus the title "The Father of History"?
What was Herodotus's method of examining the past?

options.label: B
options.text: He used only hearsay and tradition.

options.label: C
options.text: He combined different kinds of evidence, including opsis, akoe, and ta legomena.

options.label: D
options.text: He used only reason and logic.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Herodotus's work in the field of history?

options.label: A
options.text: It was the first proper history written.

options.label: B
options.text: It was the first history to focus on the internal debates of the Persian court.

options.label: C
options.text: It was the first history to record tales of Egyptian flying snakes and practical advice on how to catch a crocodile.

options.label: D
options.text: It was the first history to use reason and logic to examine the past.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of Herodotus's work on the way we understand and record history?

options.label: A
options.text: It has had a lasting impact on the way we understand and record history.

options.label: B
options.text: It has had no impact on the way we understand and record history.

options.label: C
options.text: It has only been influential in the field of ancient history.

options.label: D
options.text: It has only been influential in the field of classical studies.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main criticism of Herodotus's work?

options.label: A
options.text: He was too quick to believe some of the stories that he heard.

options.label: B
options.text: He was too slow to record the internal debates of the Persian court.

options.label: C
options.text: He was too focused on the external events of the Persian Wars.

options.label: D
options.text: He was too focused on the internal debates of the Persian court.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of Herodotus's title "The Father of History"?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a title given to him by the Roman author Cicero.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a title given to him by the Greek philosopher Aristotle.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a title given to him by the Persian king Darius.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a title given to him by the Greek historian Thucydides.

title: History vs. Che Guevara - Alex Gendler

options.label: C

options.text: He was seeking adventure and excitement.

options.text: The coup led to a peaceful transfer of power to a new government.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of Che's legacy today?

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What is the tragedy of the commons? - Nicholas Amendolare

multiple-choice.question: What is the classic problem described by economist William Forster Lloyd in 1833?

options.label: C
options.text: The law of supply and demand

multiple-choice.question: Who revived the concept of the tragedy of the commons in 1968?
What is the key feature of the tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows individuals to benefit themselves while spreading out any negative effects across the larger population

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to overgrazing, overfishing, and overpopulation

options.label: C
options.text: It is a problem that arises only in the long term

options.label: D
options.text: It is a problem that can be solved by individual action

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of the tragedy of the commons in real life?

options.label: B
options.text: The pollution from coal-fired power plants

multiple-choice.question: What is the lesson of the tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: What is good for each of us is good for all of us

options.label: B
options.text: What is good for all of us is bad for each of us

options.label: C
options.text: It is impossible to solve the tragedy of the commons

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a problem that affects human civilization

multiple-choice.question: Who has shown that humans can solve the problems of the tragedy of the commons?
What is the tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: A problem that arises when many individuals share a limited resource

options.label: B
options.text: A problem that arises when a single individual has a limited resource

options.label: C
options.text: A problem that arises when a country has a limited resource

options.label: D
options.text: A problem that arises when a company has a limited resource

options.label: A
options.text: Overgrazing, overfishing, overpopulation, pollution, and other social and environmental problems

options.label: B
options.text: Undergrazing, underfishing, underpopulation, clean air, and other social and environmental benefits

multiple-choice.question: Who first described the tragedy of the commons in 1833?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a problem that arises when many individuals share a limited resource

options.label: B
options.text: It is a problem that arises when a single individual has a limited resource

options.label: C
options.text: It is a problem that arises when a country has a limited resource

options.label: D
options.text: It is a problem that arises when a company has a limited resource

title: How often should you get a flu shot? - Melvin Sanicas

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why we need a new flu vaccine every year?

options.label: A
options.text: The flu virus has a long incubation period

options.label: B
options.text: The flu virus has multiple subtypes and can mutate quickly

options.label: C
options.text: The flu virus is transmitted through contaminated food and water

options.label: D
options.text: The flu virus is a rare disease

multiple-choice.question: How does the flu virus infect host cells?

options.label: A
options.text: By attaching to the surface of the cell and releasing its genetic material

options.label: B
options.text: By engulfing the host cell and making it into a viral production factory

options.label: C
options.text: By inserting its genetic material into the nucleus of the host cell

options.label: D
options.text: By using a built-in proofreader to correct mistakes in its genetic code

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of antigens in the flu vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce antibodies that match the antigens

options.label: B
options.text: To introduce substances found on the surface of the virus to the body

options.label: C
options.text: To create a weakened live virus that can cause illness

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent the immune system from responding to the virus

multiple-choice.question: Why is the flu vaccine less effective in some cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the virus has a long incubation period

options.label: B
options.text: Because the virus has multiple subtypes and can mutate quickly

options.label: C
options.text: Because the virus can combine with other strains to create a new hybrid virus

options.label: D
options.text: Because the vaccine is not designed to protect against mutated strains

multiple-choice.question: What is herd immunity, and how does the flu vaccine help protect others?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The flu vaccine only protects the individual who receives it

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The inhaled vaccine is only safe for people with impaired immune systems

options.label: C
options.text: The traditional flu shot contains a weakened live virus, while the inhaled vaccine contains an inactivated virus

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is a universal flu vaccine, and why is it being developed?

options.label: A
options.text: A universal flu vaccine is a vaccine that protects against all types of flu

options.label: B
options.text: A universal flu vaccine is being developed to protect against mutated strains of the flu

options.label: C
options.text: A universal flu vaccine is being developed to provide long-term protection against the flu

options.label: D
options.text: A universal flu vaccine is not being developed

multiple-choice.question: Why is it safe to get the flu vaccine even if you have a weakened immune system?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the flu vaccine contains a weakened live virus

options.label: B
options.text: Because the flu vaccine contains an inactivated virus

options.label: C
options.text: Because the flu vaccine can cause a mild illness

options.label: D
options.text: Because the flu vaccine is not effective in people with weakened immune systems

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the World Health Organization in developing the flu vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: To analyze data on circulating strains and determine which strains to include in the vaccine

options.label: B
options.text: To provide funding for the development of the flu vaccine

options.label: C
options.text: To distribute the flu vaccine to people around the world

options.label: D
options.text: To create a universal flu vaccine

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to get the flu vaccine every year?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the flu vaccine provides long-term protection against the flu

options.label: B
options.text: Because the flu vaccine is only effective for a few years

options.label: C
options.text: Because the flu virus has multiple subtypes and can mutate quickly

options.label: D
options.text: Because the flu vaccine is not necessary if you have a weakened immune system
